subSubSection.paragraph: The only member of this family in European Russia ; identified based on its long snout and large mouth. It is a widespread species in rivers and lakes but has been never recorded in karst and suffusion lakes. It is more fre-

quently observed in rivers (15.4–76.9%) than other water bodies; and most frequently at a distance over 100 km from the source. In non-river habitats, the species is more frequently found in landlocked oxbows (45.2%).
